t: Isaiah 23
Proclamation Against Tyre
The*p burden against Tyre. Wail,*pn you ships of Tarshish! For*ld it is laid waste, So*ld that there is no house, no harbor; From*ld the land of Cyprus it is revealed to them.
Be*ln still, you inhabitants of the coastland, You*ld merchants of Sidon, Whom*ld those who cross the sea have filled.
And*ld on great waters the grain of Shihor, The*ld harvest of the River, is*i her revenue; And*ld she is a marketplace for the nations.
Be*ln ashamed, O Sidon; For*ld the sea has spoken, The*ld strength of the sea, saying, “I*ld do not labor, nor bring forth children; Neither*ld do I rear young men, Nor*ild bring up virgins.”
When*ld the report reaches*i Egypt, They*ld also will be in agony at the report of Tyre.
Cross*ln over to Tarshish; Wail,*ld you inhabitants of the coastland!
Is*ild this your joyous city,*i Whose*ld antiquity is*i from ancient days, Whose*ld feet carried her far off to dwell?
Who*ld has taken this counsel against Tyre, the crowning city,*i Whose*ld merchants are*i princes, Whose*ld traders are*i the honorable of the earth?
The*ld Lord*s of hosts has purposed it, To*ld bring to dishonor the pride of all glory, To*ld bring into contempt all the honorable of the earth.
Overflow*ln through your land like the River, O*ld daughter of Tarshish; There*ild is*i no more strength.
He*ld stretched out His hand over the sea, He*ld shook the kingdoms; The*ld Lord*s has given a commandment against Canaan To*ld destroy its strongholds.
And*ld He said, “You will rejoice no more, O*ld you oppressed virgin daughter of Sidon. Arise,*ld cross over to Cyprus; There*ld also you will have no rest.”

Behold,*ln the land of the Chaldeans, This*ld people which*i was not; Assyria*ld founded it for wild beasts of the desert. They*ld set up its towers, They*ld raised up its palaces, And*ild brought it to ruin.
Wail,*ln you ships of Tarshish! For*ld your strength is laid waste.

Now*p it shall come to pass in that day that Tyre will be forgotten seventy years, according to the days of one king. At the end of seventy years it will happen to Tyre as in*i the song of the harlot:
“Take*pn a harp, go about the city, You*ld forgotten harlot; Make*ld sweet melody, sing many songs, That*ld you may be remembered.”
And*p it shall be, at the end of seventy years, that the Lord*s will deal with Tyre. She will return to her hire, and commit fornication with all the kingdoms of the world on the face of the earth.
Her gain and her pay will be set apart for the Lord;*s it will not be treasured nor laid up, for her gain will be for those who dwell before the Lord,*s to eat sufficiently, and for fine clothing.
